content.text: Tiptap Editor 3.0 Beta is out. Start here
Import and export documents with Tiptap
The Tiptap Conversion Service makes it easy to import and export content between Tiptap and document file formats. It offers:
To test or integrate this feature you need an
: Convert files (Word DOCX, OpenOffice/LibreOffice ODT, or Markdown files) into Tiptap’s JSON document format.
: Turn Tiptap JSON back into Word DOCX, OpenOffice/LibreOffice ODT, or Markdown files.
: Use built-in Tiptap Pro extensions to import/export directly within a Tiptap editor instance.
: Use HTTP endpoints to integrate our conversion services anywhere needed without a Tiptap editor being required.
We are continuously improving the conversion service. Support for page breaks, headers/footers, references like footnotes, and other complex features are in active development.
Tiptap Editor 3.0 Beta is out. Start here
Tiptap Conversion lets you import and export Tiptap JSON to and from
. You can integrate import/export directly in your Tiptap editor with dedicated extensions, or use the Conversion REST API on your server.
Most conversion operations require authentication. Generate a JWT (JSON Web Token) using the
from your Tiptap Cloud account. Include this JWT in requests or extension configs.

Depending on which format you want to work with, each file type has its own guide to installing and configuring the relevant import and export extensions:
These guides explain exactly how to integrate the respective extension and REST API endpoints into your application and configure any necessary options.
Tiptap Editor 3.0 Beta is out. Start here
(Microsoft Word) conversion with Tiptap can be done in several ways, from adding in-editor “Import/Export DOCX” buttons to using the REST API for server-side workflows.
To test or integrate this feature you need an
files directly in the editor (e.g., “Import DOCX” button), converting them to Tiptap JSON for editing. This extension makes a request to our REST API for the conversion.

to get Tiptap JSON or vice versa.
If you have custom Tiptap extensions or need deeper style control, you can override defaults or provide custom renderers for
The REST API can’t handle custom node conversions. For that, implement the Editor Export extension on your own server or on the client so you can define how those nodes convert.

The Conversion extensions are published in Tiptap’s private npm registry. Integrate the extensions by following the
Once done you can install and import the
Using the export extension does not require any Tiptap Conversion credentials, since the conversion is handled right away in the extension.

callback function that receives the exported data. You can then handle the data as needed (e.g., prompt a file download)

An array of custom node definitions. If your content includes custom nodes, pass their definitions here to ensure they're properly converted
An object with custom styles to apply to the exported document. Use this to override the default export styles

The above example runs entirely in the browser, generating a DOCX Blob via the ExportDocx extension since it's the default value for the
as we haven't override it. We then programmatically download the file. You can adjust this logic, for instance, to send the blob to a server instead of downloading.
When the conversion completes, we will get the
of the conversion as the main and only argument to the callback function which, in this case, it would be a
since we've declared that we wanted this type in the
parameter. You can then handle it however you prefer, e.g. prompting a file download, like we showcased in the example above.
We won't provide any custom node mapping since we are not providing any custom nodes.
We won't provide any style overrides, and therefore, a default
style is set following some common guideliness from Microsoft Word defaults and they will be applied to the exported document.
For applications requiring complex document generation or to reduce client-side bundle size, you can export
In order to do so, you'd need to import the
package, pass it your Tiptap JSON content, and return the resulting conversion to the client.

files from Tiptap JSON provides a way to handle most standard Word content, but
due to inherent differences between DOCX formatting and Tiptap’s CSS-based styles.
Currently supported features and known limitations:
✓ Bold, italic, underline, strikethrough, alignment, line height
✓ Paragraphs, headings (1–6), blockquotes, ordered and unordered lists
✓ Font families*, Font colors, font sizes, background colors, line heights
✗ Columns, text direction, forms, macros, embedded scripts
* Font families are supported as long as the target font is installed on the operative system when the

Tiptap Editor 3.0 Beta is out. Start here
Import and export custom nodes with .docx
One of the biggest advantages of the
extensions is the ability to define how custom nodes in your Tiptap schema should be rendered in DOCX.
This allows you to preserve application-specific content in the exported Word file.

Custom node converters must adhere to the underlying DOCX generation library’s requirements. In practice, a custom converter function for DOCX should return one of the allowed DOCX elements for that node: a
if the node should be skipped in the output.
, you can pass an array of custom node definitions in the
argument. Each definition specifies the node type and a render function.
For the sake of the example, suppose your editor has a custom node type
(a callout-styled box). You can define how it should appear in DOCX.
extension's custom node might look like:
And we will define how the
custom node should be rendered in the
Then, at a later point in your application, you can export the editor content to a
, etc.) that are provided via the
When importing a DOCX file, you can also define how custom nodes should be converted back to Tiptap nodes. This is done by passing an array of custom node definitions to the
configuration option. This option allows you to map custom nodes from the DOCX to your Tiptap schema. In the example above, we are mapping the
custom node from the DOCX to the
custom node in our Tiptap schema. By doing so, whenever the DOCX contains a
custom node, it will be converted to a
